dc:description: The DIAPH3 gene has been associated with autosomal dominant auditory neuropathy in one family segregating with a regulatory c.-172G>A variant (Schoen et al. 2010). Both heterozygous and homozygous affected individuals were identified in the consanguineous family, with homozygous individuals having an earlier onset of auditory neuropathy. This gene-disease association is supported by two transgenic mouse lines and relevant expression and functional alteration studies (20624953, 23441200). In summary, there is limited evidence to support this gene-disease association. Although more evidence is needed to support a causal role, no convincing evidence has emerged that contradicts the gene-disease association. This classification was approved by the ClinGen Hearing Loss Working Group on 2/6/2020.

evidence.dc:description: Functional assays showed variant caused overexpression. This variant is present in an affected het. and 2 affected hom. individuals in this family. Homozygous individuals had earlier onset hearing loss.

evidence.rdfs:label: Schoen Proband
evidence.detectionMethod: Linkage analysis and sequencing of all 4 genes in the linkage region
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Progressive hearing loss with onset in the second decade. OAE was normal until 5th decade of life, while electrically evoked responses of the auditory nerve were decreased, but restored by cochlear implants

evidence.dc:description: All genes in linkage region were sequenced.
evidence.rdfs:label: Schoen Family
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Progressive hearing loss with onset in the second decade. OAE was normal until 5th decade of life, while electrically evoked responses of the auditory nerve were decreased, but restored by cochlear implants

evidence.dc:description: Two mouse lines were generated by inserting a human cytomegalovirus promoter enhancer along with the Diap3 coding sequence in order to overexpress Diap3, modeling the results of the human studies in Schoen 2010. Two mouse lines were successful, and each had a progressive hearing loss with onset at either 4-8 or 16 weeks of age. By 24 weeks HL had progressed to severe at 12 and 24 kHz. Hearing was determined to be caused by inner, and not outer hair cell dysfunction, consistent with auditory neuropathy. This was based on preserved otoacoustic emissions even after progression to severe HL, indicative of preserved OHCs, and a decrease in IHC ribbons over time in Diap3-overexpressing mice. Comparison of morphological features of whole mount stereocilia showed sparseness and variable length in transgenic mice compared to WT.
evidence.rdfs:label: Animal Model 2

evidence.dc:description: Points downgraded to 0.5 because Drosophila only have one diaphanous gene, while humans have multiple, therefore this model serves as a homolog for both DIAPH3 and DIAPH1, another human hearing loss gene

DIAPH3 expression was significantly higher in homozygotes and heterozygotes compared to controls. Protein expression was also compared via immunoblots of LCL lysates. Protein levels were also significantly increased in homozygotes and heterozygotes compared to controls.
evidence.rdfs:label: Patient Cells

evidence.dc:description: This study was used to upgrade case level data.
The mutated UTR significantly upregulated the expression of luciferase gene compared to WT UTR. This demonstrates the c.-172G>A variant is sufficient to cause the overexpression of DIAPH3
evidence.rdfs:label: Non-patient cells

evidence.dc:description: Diap3 expression was detected in mouse cochlea in addition to cortex, liver, and heart tissue. Expression in the cochlea of transgenic mice described below was found to be 700-1100x higher than in WT controls
evidence.rdfs:label: Expression
